 2. While keeping your eyes open, stretch out both your arms sideways, and keep them at shoulder level. Now concentrate on moving the hands upwards and downwards from the wrist joint. While inhaling deeply, raise the hands upward from the wrist joint with the fingers together and pointed towards the sky. The palm should remain visible while doing this. 
 3. Now exhale and turn the hand downwards from the wrist joint so that the fingers now point to the floor. Repeat this sequence at least 10 times, preferably with one hand at a time. After completing the exercise, relax and place both hands on the knees. 
 4. Now concentrate on the wrist joints while keeping your eyes closed. Try to concentrate on the stretching sensation of the muscles in the forearm. Open your eyes and prepare yourself for the next set of yoga exercises.

1. Remain in the base position or a cross-legged pose. Stretch the arms
in front of the body at shoulder level. 
 2. The hands should be open with the
palms facing up. Bend the arms at the elbows and touch the fingers to the
shoulders. 
 3. Straighten the arms again. 
 4. This is one round.

1. Remain in the base position or cross leg pose. 
 2. Stretch the arms in front of the body at shoulder level. 
 3. The hands should open with the palms facing up. Bend the arms at the elbow touch the fingers to the shoulders. 
 4. Keep the upper arms parallel to the floor. Straighten the arms again. This is one round.

1. Remain in the base position or a cross-legged pose. Place the fingers of the right hand on the right shoulder. Keep the left hand on the left knee and the back straight. Rotate the right elbow in a large circle. Practice 10 times clockwise and 10 times anti-clockwise. Repeat with the left elbow. Make sure that the head, trunk and spine remain straight and still.

1. Sit in the base position or a cross-legged pose with the hands resting on the knees in jnana or chin mudra. Close the eyes. Slowly move the head forward and try to touch the chin to the chest. 
 2. Move the head as far back as comfortable. Do not strain. Try to feel the stretch of the muscles in the front and back of the neck, and the loosening
of the vertebrae in the neck. 
 3. Practice 10 times.

1. Lie in the starting position with the palms flat on the floor. Inhale and raise the right leg as high as is comfortable, keeping it straight. 
 2. The left leg should remain straight and in contact with the floor. 
 3. Hold the position for sometime while retaining the breath. 
 4. Exhale slowly, lower the leg to the floor. Repeat same with right leg.

1. Lie down and Engage the left leg muscles and keep the leg straight, in contact with the floor. 
 2. Raise the right leg 5cm from the floor, keeping the leg straight and foot relaxed. 
 3. Rotate the entire leg clockwise 5-10 times in as large a circle as comfortable. Now rotate anti-clockwise. 
 4. Release the right leg to the floor. Practice in the same way with the left leg.

1. Lie in the starting postion and relax. Bend the right knee and bring the thigh to the chest. 
 2. Interlock your fingers and clasp the hands on the shin just below the right knee. Keep the left leg straight and on the ground. 
 3. Inhale deeply, exhaling raise the head and shoulder off the ground and without straining bring the right knee to the nose. 
 4. Remain in the final position for few seconds. While slowly inhaling, return to the base position.

1. Lie flat on the back. Bend both legs to the chest. 
 2. Interlock the fingers of both the hands and clasp them around the shins just below the knees. This is the starting position. 
 3. Roll the body from side to side 5 to 10 times, touching the side of the legs on the floor.

1. Lie flat on the floor and relax. Bend the knees and place the soles of both feet flat on the foor, directly in front of the buttocks. 
 2. Keep the knees and feet together throughout the practice. 
 3. Interlock the fingers of both hands, place the palms under the back of the head and let the elbow touch the floor. Breath in and while breathing out lower the legs to the right trying to the knees down to the floor. 
 4. And at the same time turn the neck and head in the opposite direction to the legs. Repeat on the left side to complete the one round.

1. Lie in the starting position with the leg and feet together. Stretch the arms out to the sides at shoulders level with the palms of the hands facing down. 
 2. Bend the right leg and place the sole of the foot beside the left kneecap. Place the left hand on the top of the right knee. Gently bring the right knee down towards the floor on the left side of the body and foot in the contact with the left knee. 
 3. Turn the head to the right, looking along the straight arm. The left hand should be on the right knee and right hand & shoulder should remain in contact with the floor. 
 4. Hold  the position for some time. Return to the starting position bringing the head and knee to the centre. Repeat on the other side.

1. Lie on your back with your feet together and arms beside your body. 
 2. Take a deep breath in and as you exhale, lift your chest and feet off the ground, stretching your arms towards your feet. 
 3. Your eyes, fingers and toes should be in a line. Feel the tension in your navel area as the abdominal muscles contract. 
 4. Keep breathing deeply and easily while maintaining the pose. As you exhale, come back to the ground slowly and relax.

1. Sit on the floor with both legs straight in front. Separate the legs as far apart as possible. Keep the knees straight. 
 2. Raise and stretch the arms side ways at shoulder level as shown. Keep the arms straight. Exhale and slowly twist the trunk to the left and bring the right hand towards the left big toe. Stretch the left arm behind the back. 
 3. Keep both arms in one straight line. Turn the head to the left and look at the left hand fingertips. Hold the posture for 30 seconds. Inhale and bring the trunk to the center.

1. Sit with the legs straight in front of the body about 1 foot apart. Interlock the fingers of both hands and hold the arms out straight in front of the chest. Keep the arms straight horizontal through out the practice; do not bend the elbows. 
 2. Bend forward maximum without straining. Imagine the action of churning the mill with an old fashioned stone grinder. Rotate to the right so that the hand pass above the right toes as far to the right as possible. 
 3. Lean back as far as possible on the backward rotation. Try to move the body from the hips. 
 4. On the forward rotation, bring the arms and the hands to the left side, over the left toes and then back to the center position. One rotation is one round, practice 5-10 rounds clockwise and then the same number of rounds anti-clockwise direction.

1. Sit with both legs outstretched. Imagine the way of rowing a boat. Clench the hands like grasping oars of the boat, with the palms facing down. 
 2. Exhale and bend forward from the waist as front as is comfortable, straightening the arms. Inhale and lean backward. 
 3. Lean back as much as possible, bringing the hands towards the shoulders. The hand should make a complete circular movement. 
 4. Exhale and bend forward from the waist to the frontward. The legs are kept straight throughout the practice. Do 5-10 rounds of this practice.
Then reverse the direction as though going in the opposite direction. Practice 5-10 rounds.

1. Sit in the squatting position. Keep the feet flat on the floor 1 - 2 feet apart. The knees are fully bent. The elbows should be inside the knees.
Clasp the fingers of both hands together and place them on the floor between the feet. 
 2. Keep the arms straight throughout the practice. 
 3. Imagine the action of chopping wood. Inhale and raise the arms high above and behind the head, stretching the spine upward. Look up towards the hands. 
 4. Forcefully exhale and make a downward stroke with the arms, like chopping wood. The hands should return near the floor in between the feet. This is one round. Practice 5 to 10 rounds.

1. Lie flat on the back with the arms about 15 cm away from the body, palms facing upward. Let the fingers curl up slightly.
Move the feet slightly apart to a comfortable position and close the eyes. 
 2. The head and spine should be in a straight line. Make sure the head does not fall to one side or the other. 
 3. Relax the whole body and stop all physical movement.
Become aware of the natural breath and allow it to become rhythmic and relaxed. 
 4. After some time, again become aware of the body and surroundings, and gently and smoothly release the posture.

1. Lie down on the stomach. Stretch both arms above the head with the palms facing downwards. The forehead should be touching the floor. 
 2. Relax the whole body with the slow and deep breathing. If there is any difficulty in breathing or suffocation, a pillow may be placed under the chest to ease the posture. 
 3. Continue resting on this pose and after sometime gently and smoothly release the posture.

1. Lie flat on the stomach with legs straight and the forehead resting on the mat. 
 2. Interlock the fingers and place the palms on the back of the head or neck Or It could be performed with the fingers of hands interlocked and placed under the forehead, palms facing up. 
 3. Place the relaxed elbows on the floor. Relax the whole body and become aware of natural & rhythmic breathing. 
 4. Stay in this posture some time, then gently and smoothly release the posture.

1.Lie flat on the stomach. Raise the head and shoulders. Bend the hands at the elbow and rest the elbows on the floor. Cup the chin into the palms of the hands. Separate the elbows with some space. 
 2. Adjust the position of the elbows so that there is no pressure on the neck or lower back. 
 3. Relax the whole body and close the eyes. Feel the well-being on your neck, lower back and the whole body. 
 4. Stay in this relaxed posture some time, then gently and smoothly release the posture.

1. Lie flat on the stomach. Keep the fingers interlocked under the head. Bend the left leg sideways and bring the left knee close to the ribs. 
 2. The right leg should remain straight. Twist both arms to the left so that the left elbow rest near the left knee. 
 3. Rest the right side of the head on the right arm. Relax in this final position and after some time, change sides. 
 4. Breathing is normal and relaxed in this pose.

1. Sit in Vajrasana. Place on top of the heels so the fingers are pointing towards each other. 
 2. If this is uncomfortable, place the palms just above the heels. 
 3. Keep the head and spine erect,close the eues and relax the whole body. Fix the attention at the eyebrow centre.

1. Sit in vajrasana. Place the palms on top of the heels so that the fingers are pointing towards each other. 
 2. If this is uncomfortable, place the palms just above the heels. 
 3. Keep the head and spine erect, close the eyes and relax the whole body. 
 4. Fix the attention at the eyebrow centre.

1. Sit in Vajrasana. Cross the arms in front of the chest, placing the hands under opposite armpits with the thumbs pointing upward. 
 2. Close the eyes and become aware of the breathing process.

1. Sit in vajrasana with the knees about 45 cm apart. The toes of the both feet should remain in contact with each other. Lean forward and place the palms of the hands on the floor between the knees, with fingers pointing towards the body. 
 2. Straighten the arms fully and arch the back. Open the eyes and gaze at the eyebrow centre. 
 3. Relax the whole body, keep the mouth close. Inhale slowly and deeply through the nose. 
 3. At the end of inhalation open the mouth and extend the tounge out as far as possible towards the chin. 
 4. While slowly exhaling, produce a clear steady 'aaa' sound from the throat, keeping the mouth wide open. 
 5. At the end of the exhalation close the mouth and breath in.

1. Sit in vajrasana. Raise the buttocks and stand on the knees. Lean forward and place the hands flat on the floor beneath the shoulder with fingers facing forward. 
 2. The hands should be in line with the knees; the arms and thighs should be perpendicular to the floor. 
 3. The knees must be slightly seprated so that they are well aligned under the hips. This is the starting position. Inhale while raising the head and depressing the spine so that the back becomes concave. 
 4. Expand the abdomen fully and fill the lungs with the maximum amount of the air. Hold the breath for 3 seconds. Exhale while lowering the head and stretching the spine upward. At the end of exhalation, contract the abdomen and pull in the buttocks. The head will now be between the arms, facing the thighs. 
 5. Hold the breath for 3 seconds, accentuating the arch of the spine and abdominal contraction.

1. Set yourself in Marjari asana. Inhale while raising your right leg towards the back until it is parallel to the ground. Fold the lower knee slowly bringing it towards the head. Your sole should face towards your back. Turn your neck upward and backward as much as you can. 
 2. Keep your eyes open focusing between the centre of eyebrows. Balance your body in this position as long as you can. Exhale and bend down your neck at the same time bringing your right knee down. 
 3. Inhale and bring your right knee between the arms and try to touch the nose with this knee while breathing out. Raise your back upwards and hold this position for a while. Now, get to the original Marjariasana placing back your right knee to its initial position and the neck to normal level facing straight. 
 4. Take a small break, repeat the same steps with your left leg; this completes the cycle.

1. Sit in Vajrasana, the thunderbolt pose or the kneeling pose. Place your hands on the thighs and breathe in a relaxed manner. 
 2. Raise both your hands above the head with palms facing forward. The arms should be in line with the shoulders. 
 3. Slowly bend down and bring the hands forward, till the hands and forehead touches the ground. Exhale while you are bending forward. 
 4. In the final position, the forehead and hands should rest on the ground. Rest in this position for as long as you are comfortable. In the final position slow rhythmic and relaxed breathing can be done.

1. Assume the final position of shashankasana. Now inhale slowly and while inhaling, lift your buttocks slowly, slide your body forward by brushing your nose on the floor. This will bring the entire body weight on the palms and wrists. 
 2. Arch your back by pressing it down in such a way that head, chest and shoulders are off the ground. Keep the arms straight and steady. 
 3. Stay in this position for a minute or so, then exhale and come back to the starting position by raising the buttocks and pushing them backwards. Buttocks should sit on the heels as it was in the starting by again assuming final shashankasna pose. 
 4. Remember to inhale when you move forward and exhale when move backward.

1. Sit in vajrasana. Bend forward and bring the crown of the head on the floor ( If needed, place a folded blanket under the head for more comfortable pose ). 
 2. Grasp the lower calves above the ankles. 
 3. Raise the buttocks as high as possible, allowing the chin to press against the chest. 
 4. Hold this final position for some time. Then slowly lower the buttocks and come to shashankasana for a shorter time before returning to vajrasana.

1. Sit in vajrasana. Stand up on the knees with the arms at the sides. Keep the feet flat behind the body Or you can curl-in the feet. 
 2. Inhale, stretch the arms sideways and raise them to shoulder level. Twist to the right, reach back with the right hand and hold the left heel or ankle. 
 3. Simultaneously, stretch the left arm in front of the head. The head should be slightly back with the eyes gazing at the raised left hand. Push the abdomen forward and try to keep the thighs vertical. 
 4. With normal breathing, hold this final position for a few seconds. Inhale and return to the starting position. Repeat the practice on the other side.

1. Stand on knees with knees little apart and feet stretched out. Lean back and catch hold of right heel with right hand and then the left heel with left hand. 
 2. Push the abdomen forward, drop the head back and arch backward as far as you can. 
 3. Hold as long as comfortable, breathe normally. Do not try to breathe deeply because the chest is already stretched. 
 4. Slowly release one hand then the other and come back to start position.

1. Sit in vajrasan (kneeling position with the buttocks on your heels). Slowly bend backwards taking the support of first the right elbow and arm then the left. 
 2. Hold the ankle with your hands and arch the head back. Slowly lower the back and head to the ground as you hold your ankle with your hands. Try to keep the knees on the ground. 
 3. Close your eyes and relax in this posture. Breathe deeply and slowly. 
 4. Return to the starting position in the reverse order, breathing in and taking the support of the elbows and arms.Never leave the final position by straightening the legs first; this may dislocate the knee joint.

1. Stand with the feet together and arms beside the body. Balance the weight of the body equally on both feet. 
 2. Cross the wrists in front of the body. Slowly raise the arms above the head, keeping the wrists crossed. 
 3. Simultaneously, raise the head to gaze at the hands. Spread the arms out to the sides at shoulder height. 
 4. Hold for a few seconds then reverse the movement by recrossing the wrists above the head. Lower the arms straight down in front of the body and return the head back to centre.

1. Stand straight with the feet shoulder width apart and the arms at the sides. Take a short step forward with the left leg. Clench the left arm fist and bring it over the left foot; it should be slightly above eye level. 
 2. Clench the right arm fist and bring it slightly behind the left fist. Look at the left fist like you are holding a bow and arrow, and fix the eyes on an imaginary target. 
 3. Inhale and pull the right fist backward to the right ear, tensing both arms as if drawing the bow. The head should slightly move back so the neck muscles become stretched tight. 
 4. Exhale and release the imaginary arrow. Bring the right fist forward close to the left fist. Relax the neck.

1. Stand with your legs stretched apart. Stretch your arms outwards and come up on your toes. Fix the eyes at a point on the wall slightly above the level of the head. The eyes should remain fixed on this point throughout the practice. 
 2. Inhale and take your hands up and join your palms. 
 3. Stretch the whole body upwards without losing the balance or moving the feet. 
 4. Hold the posture for 10-30 seconds. Lower the heels while breathing out.

1. Widen your feet litter more than your shoulders. The toes should be pointing towards the front, spread nicely to make sure that your body weight is evenly distributed between both the feet. At this point, bend the knees slightly, tuck your hips under and then straighten the legs. 
 2. Now, roll your shoulders back, open your chest and raise both arms above the head stretching upwards while inhaling. Your palms should be facing towards each other. 
 3. From the Abdominal, bend right while exhaling. Hold this position for a few seconds, inhale and get back to the centre while exhaling. Inhale and now bend left from the Abdominal while exhaling, hold the position for a few seconds, inhale and get back to centre while exhaling. 
 4. This completes one cycle. To release the pose, exhale while bringing your arms back down and then to both sides.

1. Stand with the feet about shoulder width apart. 
 2. Both the arms should be out-stretched in front of the chest while palms are facing to each other. It should be ensured that distance between the arms remain constant. 
 3. While exhaling, swing the arms to the right side as far as possible by rotating the abdominal. Maintain the pose as long as you can. While inhaling, bring your arms before the chest. 
 4. The same thing may be followed while bending your arms towards the left side.

1. Stand erect with the feet about shoulder width apart. Interlock the fingers in front of the body. 
 2. Raise the arms over the head and rotate the wrist, turning the palms out. Bend forward from the hips to form a right angle between the legs and trunk. 
 3. Watch the back of the hands and keep the back straight. Slowly swing the arms and trunk to the right as far as is comfortable, then to the left and then back to the center. 
 4. Return to the upright position and lower the arms.

1. Stand erect with the feet shoulder width apart and the toes turned slightly out to the side. Place the fingers of both hands on the shoulders with the elbows pointing sideways. 
 2. This is the starting position. Twist the upper torso to the right as far as is comfortable and then return to the center. 
 3. Repeat on the left side. Practice 5 to 10 times on each side.

1. Stand erect with the feet about one metre apart. 
 2. Turn the toes out to the sides where they remain throughout the practice. 
 3. Interlock the fingers of both hands and let them hang loosely in front of the body. Lower the buttocks until the hands rest on or as near as possible to the floor. 
 4. Keep the arms and shoulder loose and avoid bending forward. Stay in this position for sometime. Then return to the upright position.

1. Stand erect with both the feet together and facing forward. Place the palms together in front of the chest. 
 2. While inhaling, raise and straighten the arms above the head. 
 3. While breathing out, slowly lower the body, bending the knees. 
 4. Keep the feet and knees together throughout the practice.

1. Stand with the feet together and the arms by the sides. Raise the arms straight up above the head. Bend the wrists so that the fingers are pointing forward. Allow the hands to hang limp. 
 2. Arch the back slightly, pushing the buttocks out a little. Slowly bend forward at the hips, keeping the legs straight, until the back is horizontal and forms a right angle with the legs. 
 3. Keep the head, neck and spine in a straight line. Look forward. Hold the final position for up to 5 seconds. 
 4. Slowly return to the upright position, with the arms, head and back in a straight line. Lower the arms. Practice 3 to 5 rounds.

1. Stand straight with the feet 30 cm apart. Keep the arms behind the back and interlock the fingers. 
 2. Exhale and bend forward from the hips so that the back and the face are parallel with the floor. 
 3. Raise the arms behind the back as high as possible without strain. The arms act as a lever and accentuate the stretch given to the shoulders and chest. 
 4. Hold the final position for some time, then lower the arms to the back. Inhale and then return to the upright position.

1. Stand erect with your legs wide apart. Turn the right foot to the right side. Inhale, stretch the arms sideways and raise till shoulder level in one straight line. 
 2. Exhale, and bend the right knee slightly. Then bend the body to the right side (not frontwards, not backwards but exactly to the sides). 
 3. Place the right hand parallel to the right foot, keeping the two arms in line with each other. Look up at the left hand finger tips. 
 4. Hold this final position for some time. 
 5. Then inhale and return to the upright position with the arms in a straight line. Repeat the practice on the opposite side, bending the left knee slightly.

1. Stand erect with your legs wide apart. Turn the right foot to the right side. Inhale, stretch the arms sideways and raise till shoulder level in one straight line. 
 2. Exhale, and bend the right knee slightly. Then bend the body to the right side (not frontwards, not backwards but exactly to the sides). 
 3. Place the right hand parallel to the right foot, and lower the upper arm over the ear until it is parallel to the floor with the palm facing down. Look up at the left hand finger tips. 
 4. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat on the left side.

1. Stand erect with your legs wide apart and the toes facing forward. Bring the palms of the hands on each side of the abdominal and the fingers pointing downward. 
 2. Exhale, slowly bend the body to the right from the hips while sliding the right hand down along the outside of the left thigh. Simultaneously bend the right knee slightly, rest the right hand palm on the floor. 
 3. Holding the breath, stay in this final position for some time. 
 4. Inhale and raise the trunk to the upright position, and return the right hand to the abdominal. Repeat on the left side to complete one round.

1. Stand erect with the feet about a metre apart. While breathing in, raise the arms sideways to shoulder level. While breathing out, bend forward. Twist the trunk to the left, bringing the right hand to the left foot. 
 2. The left arm should be outstretched vertically so that both arms form a straight line. Look up at the left hand. 
 3. Hold the breath in the final position for some seconds, feeling the twist and stretch of the back. 
 4. Return to the centre forward position. Raise the body to the starting position while breathing in, keeping the arms outstretched to the sides. Repeat with the other side.

1. Stand with legs wide apart. While inhaling raise both arms above the head and allow the wrists to relax so that the hands drop forward. Exhaling bend the upper body forward. 
 2. Breathing normally allow the upper body and arms to hang relaxed for a short while. Inhaling raise the upper body and arms to horizontal. 
 3. Exhaling swing the upper body and arms down between the legs. Repeat the raising and swinging of the upper body and arms 10 times in rhythm with the breath. 
 4. Breathing normally allow the upper body and arms to hang relaxed for a while. Inhaling slowly come upright and stretch the arms upwards. The hands fall forwards relaxed. Exhaling return to starting position.

1. Stand with the feet more than shoulder width apart. Raise the arms and interlock the fingers behind the neck with the elbows pointing sideways. 
 2. Turn slightly to the right and bend forward, keeping the feet firmly on ground. Bring the head as close as comfortable to the right knee. 
 3. The legs should remain straight throughout the practice. Swing the upper torso from the right to left knee and back to the right knee. Repeat 3 times. 
 4. Return to the centre and stand upright. Repeat with the swing starting from the left knee. This is one round, and is usually sufficient.

1. Stand erect with the feet held together. 
 2. Bring the two hands together and the palms touching each other at the chest level. Look straight ahead. 
 3. Breathe in normally. This will give a sense of relaxation.

1. Stand erect and raise both the hands above the head. 
 2. Let there be shoulders length between the two arms. 
 3. Bend the trunk and head backwards to create a slight curve. 
 4. Raising the arms and bending the trunk backwards is done at the same time. Breathe in deeply while raising the arms.

1. Stand erect and bend the body forward. Let the arms touch the floor. If it is difficult take the arms only as far as it is possible without straining. Exhale as you bend forward. 
 2. Bring the trunk closer to the legs. Try to touch the knees with the forehead. This may require lot of flexibility. In the initial stages, take it only as far as it is comfortable. 
 3. Padahastasana is done as the 3rd pose and the 10th pose in surya namaskar.

1. Start with standing position, both feet together and hands by the sides of your body. 
 2. Exhale and bend forward so that your palm comes flat on the floor by the sides of your feet, you can bend your knees if its not possible with straight legs. 
 3. Inhale and stretch the right leg back as far as is comfortable and grasp the floor with the toes. Bend the left knee keeping the left foot on the floor at the same position. 
 4. Arch your back, roll your shoulder back and tilt your head back with the fingers touching the ground. Stay in the posture for a few breaths. Come back to starting position.

1. From Ashwa Sanchalanasana, straighten the bend leg and take it backwards. Exhale during this process. Let the right and left foot be together. 
 2. Raise the buttocks up. Let the two arms be on the floor and support the body weight. 
 3. Lower the head to be between the two arms. The body makes the shape of a triangle when observed from the sides. It looks like a mountain and hence the name.

1. Lower the body so that the body is parallel to the ground. 
 2. Let the following parts touch the floor - The two feet, the two knees, the two palms, the chest and the chin. 
 3. The hip and abdomen is slightly raised up. 
 4. While performing this pose the breath is held outside and the breathing is stopped for few seconds.

1. Lie down on your stomach with hands on the side, toes touching together. Bring your hands to the front at the shoulder level, with palms resting on the floor. 
 2. Slowly raise your trunk and head with the support of the palms alone. The arms should be bent at the elbows. 
 3. Arch your neck slightly backwards, so that the pose looks like a cobra with raised hood. Breathe normally and feel the stomach press against the floor. 
 4. Hold the asana for few seconds in the beginning stage. One may go up to 2 minutes as one progresses. You can release the pose by bringing the hands back to the sides and resting your head on the forehead.

1. Lie flat on the stomach, with your chin on the floor, legs straight, feet together and the toes pointing backwards. 
 2. Bend the elbows and place the hands shoulder width apart beside the head, fingertips in line with the crown of the head. Keep the elbows tucked in to the sides of the body. 
 3. Inhale, and lift your head, chest and shoulders up, so that elbows are at ninety degrees. The forearm will still be resting on the ground. 
 4. Keep the shoulders down and away from the ears, and the chest broad. Hold the position for a comfortable amount of time breathing normally. Exhale, lower the body down.

1. Lie down on your stomach. Legs straight with toes pointing backwards (feet can be together or apart depending on the flexibility). 
 2. Place the palm on the floor on the sides of the shoulder, with fingers pointing forward. Position the arms so that the elbows point backwards and are close to the body. 
 3. Inhale and straighten the arms to lift the chest off the floor, rise only to the point till the pubic bone is in contact with the floor. Press the pubis into the ground and try to arch your back further and look over your right shoulder. 
 4. The arms may or may not be straight depending on the flexibility of the back. Hold the pose anywhere from 15 to 30 seconds, breathing easily. Come back to the floor with an exhalation. Repeat the same on the other side.

1. Lie flat on your stomach. Put the palms besides the ears. Inhale deeply and exhale. 
 2. Stretch your palm on the floor and bring up your chest, neck and stomach. Your hip and the lower portions must be placed on the floor. 
 3. Spread your legs straight, at the same time bend your neck backside and see the roof as much as possible. 
 4. 10 seconds are enough with the exhaled lungs. The people who cannot remain in the exhaled lungs can take a small breath at that state. Put your head on the floor, turn it left or right then relax for few seconds.

1. Lie down on your stomach with legs closed together and hands on the sides. Make sure your abdomen, chest and chin are touching the ground. 
 2. Clench your fists and keep them facing upwards. Inhale and hold your breath. Taking support of the fist, raise your left leg backwards straight up, without bending the knee. 
 3. The body from navel upwards should be on the ground. Hold the leg in the raised position for 5 seconds. 
 4. Keep your right leg straight and steady. Exhale slowly and bring your left leg down. Complete exhalation. Repeat the same steps with your right leg.

1. Lie on your stomach with the chin stretched and touching the ground. Keep the hands on the side. Slowly bring your hands under the legs to support them. 
 2. You should lift both the legs together. Maintain this position for few seconds, maximum up to half a minute. 
 3. Slowly release the position by bringing down the right leg back to the original position. Exhale during this process. 
 4. Rest for few seconds and breathe normally and deeply. Now, try the above steps with your left leg lifted above the ground.

1. Assume the starting position for dhanurasana, lying flat on the stomach and holding the bent legs at the ankles, with the hands. Relax the whole body. 
 2. Tense the legs and try to push the feet backward while raising the head and chest. Do not try to raise the thighs off the ground. 
 3. Maintain the final pose for a comfortable period of time and then slowly return to the floor. 
 4. Repeat when the respiration rate returns to normal.

1. Lie flat on the stomach with the legs and feet together, and the arms and hands beside the body. 
 2. Exhale, bend your knees and hold the ankles with hands. While inhaling raise the thighs, head and chest as high as possible. 
 3. Try to maintain weight of the body on lower abdomen. Join the ankles. Look upward and breathe normally. 
 4. While exhaling, bring down the head and legs up to knee joint. Maintain this position as long as you can hold and slowly come back to the original position.

1. Lie down flat on the back on your yoga mat. Bend the legs at the knees and bring the feet close to the buttocks. Grab the ankles with the hands and pull it backwards till the feet touches the buttocks. 
 2. Retain the breath inside and raise the buttocks. Also arch the back upwards. The feet and the shoulder portion should remain on the ground. 
 3. In this position, the body weight is supported by the feet, the shoulders, the arms, the neck and the head. This is the final pose. Retain it for as long as you are comfortable. 
 4. To release the asana, bring down the buttocks back to the ground. The knees can remain in the bend position. Repeat this for 5 to 10 times depending on strength and convenience.

1. First of all stand in normal Tadasana or Mountain Pose with both feet touching each other. 
 2. Now keep both hands together closer to the chest with palms slightly pressed towards each other. 
 3. Now inhale and raise arms straight upward with palms slightly pressed towards each other. Now steadily arch the body on either left or right hand-side by placing arms together lined with neck and head as much as possible and retain this posture by keeping the knees straight. 
 4. At last exhale steadily and get yourself to initial Tadasana posture. Repeat the same process on other side and avoid bending in front side of the body.

1. Lie on the stomach with the arms cross under the chest, the hands holding the upper arms. Separate the legs slightly and keep the feet flat. 
 2. Raise the head so that the face looks forward. This is the starting position. 
 3. The elbows should not move during the practice. Raise the trunk and buttocks so that the body is supported by the knees and elbows. 
 4. Stretch the torso back, placing the chin and chest on, or as close as possible to the floor behind the forearms. Return to the raised position and then to the starting position.

1. Lie on the mat with your back on the floor. Now lift your hips upwards  as much you can (should not over-stretch) by pressing your palms. 
 2. Keep breathing deeply in this position for some time for 20-30 seconds. 
 3. Now relax by touching your hips to the ground i.e. your starting position. 
 4. Repeat this cycle for 3-4 times.

1. Sit in Dhyana veerasana so that the right knee is directly above the left knee. Stretch the left arm to the side and then fold it behind the back. 
 2. Stretch the right arm up above the head, then fold it over right shoulder. The back of the left hand should lie in contact with the spine while palm of the rigt hand should rest againt the spine. 
 3. Try to clasp the fingers of both hands behind the back. 
 4. The spine should be erect and the head back. Close teh eyes and stay in this position for 2 minutes. Unclasp the hands, straighten the legs and repeat with opposite side.

1. Sit on the blanket with the legs outstretched in front of the body. Separate the knees, moving the legs apart. Bend the right leg and place the sole of the right foot against the inside of the left thigh, allowing the whole of the right leg to rest on the floor. 
 2. Carefully fold your left leg to the outside of the body so that the foot lies beside the left buttock. Place your hands on your right ankle. Relax your whole body and exhale. 
 3. Then as you inhale, slowly raise your arms upwards, keeping them together and straight until they are eventually vertical above the head at the end of inhalation. 
 4. Then exhale, twist the trunk slightly and bend forwards over the right knee. Try to touch your forehead on the ground directly in front of the right knee. 
 5. At first this may be a little difficult, but with practice it becomes possible. If you canât touch the floor with your forehead merely bend forwards as far as possible. Your hands should touch the floor in front of the body, with the arms kept straight, though preferably slightly bent and completely relaxed. 
 6. Relax your whole body. This is the final position. Then as you inhale, raise the arms, head and trunk until your arms are vertical. Exhale and lower your arms. 
 7.  Now adjust the body position so that the left sole presses against the right thigh, and the right leg is folded backwards. Repeat the same procedure but now bending over the left knee.

1. Sit up with the legs stretched out straight in front of you on the floor. Keep the spine erect and toes flexed towards you. Bring your respiration to normal. 
 2. Breathing in, slowly raise your both the arms straight above your head and stretch up. Slowly breathe out and bend forward from the hip joint, chin moving toward the toes keeping the spine erect. 
 3. Place your hands on your legs, wherever they reach, without putting much effort. If possible hold of your toes and pull on them to help you go forward. 
 4. Stay in this position as long as possible. After the exertion limit reached inhale and raise up stretching up your arms straight above your head. 
 5. Breathe out and bring your arms down placing the palms on the ground. Relax for a while and try to feel the changes occurred in the body.

1. Lie flat on the back with the feet together. Raise arms over the head and bring them to the floor with the palms facing up. 
 2. Relax the whole body. Raise the trunk to the sitting position with the arms stretched above the head and spine straight. Bend forward into paschimottasana in smooth movement. 
 3. Hold the final position for short time. Return to the sitting position with the arms straight above the head. 
 4. Lean backward and return o the strting position. This is one round.

1. Sit with legs straight and wide apart. Hands rest on the thighs. Inhaling raise both arms above the head. 
 2. Exhaling bend forward from the hips, keep the back as straight as possible and grasp the toes. Pull the upper body even further forward until the forehead touches the floor. The legs remain straight. 
 3. Breathing normally hold this position. Inhaling bring the body upright keeping the arms straight. 
 4. Exhaling place the hands on the thighs.

1. Sit on the floor with both the legs stretched out in front of you. Now bend the right leg and bring the feet close to the left thighs. Let the sole of the right foot touch the inner left thigh. 
 2. Adjust the right foot so that it touches the right groin. Stretch the right bend leg as far back as possible without strain. The left leg should remain the straight position with toes pointing upwards. 
 3. Take a deep breath and take your arms above the head in line with your ears. Now exhale slowly and bend the body forward. Let the hands go forward and grab the left foot either by the toes or the middle of the foot depending on which is more comfortable. Pull your trunk forward until your forehead touches the knees. 
 4. Remain in this position for as long as you are comfortable. One can hold the breath if you remain in the position for few seconds. Else for longer durations, one can breathe normally in the final position. To release the position, raise your trunk to upright sitting position. Inhale while coming back to the sitting pose. Release the right leg and stretch it in front of you to come back to the starting position where both legs are stretched out in front of you. Repeat this pose with the other leg.

1. Lie on the right side with the arms stretched over the head so that the whole body is balanced in one straight line along the floor. The palm of the left hand should rest on top of the palm of the right hand. 
 2. The left foot should rest on top of the right foot.This is the starting position. 
 3. Keep the arms and legs straight throughout the practice. Raise the left arm and leg to a 45 degree angle above the floor. Hold the position for a short duration, maintaining balance on the side of the body. 
 4. Lower the leg and arm to the starting position. Raise the left leg and arm to their full extent and, keeping them straight, take hold of the big toe without bending the knee. If this is impossible, take hold of a suitable point on the leg to give support while gently stretching the hip. 
 4. This is the final position. Hold the final position for a short duration. Lower the arm and leg to the starting position. Practice a maximum of 5 times on this side. Roll over to the other side and repeat the movement.

1. Lie on the right side with the left leg on top of the right leg. Bend the right arm, placing the elbow on the floor. Raise the torso and head, supporting them on the right elbow. Rest the head in the right palm. The forearm and upper arm should be nearly vertical. 
 2. Place the left arm on the left thigh. This is the starting position. Raise the left leg as high as possible, slide the left hand to the foot and grasp the big toe. If this is too difficult, hold the leg as close to the foot as possible. 
 3. Keep the legs straight. This is the final position. 
 4. Lower the raised leg and arm to the starting position. Practice a maximum of 10 times. Repeat on the other side.

1. Sit on the floor with legs stretched forward. Relax the trunk and keep the spine straight. Place the palms on the side of the buttocks fingers pointing backwards. 
 2. Bring the left hand to the right and place the left palm next to the right palm. Place the left foot outside the right knee. 
 3. Twist the head and trunk to the right as far as it is comfortable. Retain the breath during the twisting process. Exhale in the final position. One can also continue with slow and deep breathing in the final position. 
 4. Bring back the trunk and legs to starting position and repeat the process on the left side by placing the right foot next to the left knee and twisting the body to the left side. Do as many rounds as you are comfortable.

1. Sit with the spine erect and the legs outstretched. Place the hands to the side of the right hip. Move the right hand back slightly further behind the body with the fingers pointing backward. 
 2. Twist the trunk 90 degrees to the right, using the arms and shoulders as levers. Slowly bend the torso and bring the forehead to the floor, close to the hand placed behind the body. The spine should be as straight as possible. 
 3. Try to keep both buttocks on the floor. Hold the final position for a short time. 
 4. Slowly raise and return to the starting position. Repeat the movement on the other side. This completes one round. Practice up to 5 rounds.

1. Sit up with the legs stretched out straight in front of you, keeping the feet together and the spine erect. Bend the left leg and place the heel of the left foot beside the right hip (optionally, you can keep the left leg straight). 
 2. Take the right leg over the left knee. Place the left hand on the right knee and the right hand behind you. Twist the abdominal, shoulders and neck in this sequence to the right and look over the right shoulder. 
 3. Keep the spine erect. Hold and continue with gentle long breaths in and out. 
 4. Breathing out, release the right hand first (the hand behind you), release the abdominal, then chest, lastly the neck and sit up relaxed yet straight. Repeat to the other side. Breathing out, come back to the front and relax.

1. Sit in Dandasana with a straight spine. Spread your legs apart as far as possible. 
 2. Now check which of your nostrils is active. If you are breathing from the right nostril, place your right hand on your left thigh, so that your arm comes in front of you. 
 3. Bend down to your right leg and place your right shoulder on your thigh. 
 4. Now stretch your left arm over your head and reach in the direction of your right foot so that your left side is stretched nicely. If you can, grab your right toes with your left hand. Repeat the same on your left side.

1. Stand erect on the floor with hands on the sides. Look straight ahead and breathe normally. 
 2. Bring the two palms together in the prayer pose. Raise the right leg and place the sole of the right foot on the inner side of the upper left thigh. 
 3. Maintain balance and remain in this position for as long as you are comfortable. Breathe normally during the final pose. 
 4. One can fix the gaze ahead on an object of concentration. Try to maintain awareness along with the breathing process. To release the pose, bring back the raised foot to the standing position. One can try this asana with the left leg raised as well.

1. Stand with the feet together and the arms beside the body. Slowly transfer the weight onto the left leg. 
 2. Raise the right foot from the floor and bend the knee slightly. Place the outside of the ankle in front of the left shin, so that the sole of the right foot is almost vertical to the floor. 
 3. Raise both hands to the right and as if playing a flute, turn the right palm forward and the left palm backward. Extend the index and little fingers of the hands, and wrap the thumbs around the curled middle and ring fingers. 
 4. Turn the head to the left and gaze softly at a fixed point to maintain steady balance. Hold the position for as long as comfortable. To release, lower the hands then the foot and redistribute the weight evenly. Repeat with the left leg, then practice up to 3 times on each side.

1. Begin by standing in Tadasana. Bend your knees and lift your left foot and cross it over the right one. 
 2. Ensure that right foot is firmly placed on the floor and the left thigh is over the right thigh. Your left footâs toe should be pointing downwards. Bring your arms forwards while keeping them parallel to the floor. 
 3. Cross the right arm over the left one and bend your elbows so that your arms are now perpendicular to the floor. Ensure that the back of your hands are facing each other. Slowly turn the hands so that the palms face each other. 
 4. Pressing the palms together, stretch the fingers upwards. Keeping your gaze focused at one place, stay in this pose for a couple of breaths. Slowly release the hands and bring them to the side of your body. Raise your left leg and place it back on the floor and slowly come back into Tadasana.

1. Stand with the feet together and the arms beside the body. Find a point in front of the body to fix the gaze. Bend the right leg and raise it until the right thigh is parallel to the floor. 
 2. Point the right foot a little to the left, so the heel is in front of the left knee. Bend the right arm and place it across the body in line with the right thigh. 
 3. Allow the right hand to limp with the fingers pointing down. Bend the left elbow and position it above the right wrist with the forearm vertical. Curl the index finger to the base of the left thumb and form jnana mudra with the left hand, position the palm forward. 
 4. Hold the position for as long as comfortable. To release, lower the hands then the foot and redistribute the weight evenly. Repeat with the left leg, then practice up to 3 times on each side.

1. Stand with the feet together and the arms beside the body. Bend right knee and take a hold of the right ankle with right hand behind the body. 
 2. Raise the left arm up and forward, curl the index finger to the base of the left thumb to form jnana mudra. Keeping the hips aligned, slowly raise and stretch the right leg backward, as high as comfortable. 
 3. Gaze softly at the left hand. Hold for as long as comfortable. 
 4. Release the posture by reversing the order of movements then repeat with left leg. Practice up to 3 rounds to each side.

1. Stand with the feet together and the arms beside the body. Bend right knee and take a hold of the right ankle with right hand behind the body. 
 2. Raise the left arm up and forward, curl the index finger to the base of the left thumb to form jnana mudra. Keeping the hips aligned, slowly raise and stretch the right leg backward, as high as comfortable. 
 3. Gaze softly at the left hand. Hold for as long as comfortable. 
 4. Release the posture by reversing the order of movements then repeat with left leg. Practice up to 3 rounds to each side.

1. Stand straight and raise your hands above the head. Inhale while raising your hand, expanding the chest. Interlock the fingers and hold the hands together. 
 2. Bend forward slowly with arms stretched out in front of you. Exhale while bending forward. Simultaneously, raise the left leg and take it backwards. 
 3. Keep bending forward till your body is parallel to the ground. At the same time, take your left leg backwards so that it is perpendicular to the right leg. The entire body weight is supported on the left foot alone. 
 4. In the final pose, the hands, body, trunk and legs are in a straight line, parallel to the ground. The whole body is perpendicular or at 90 degrees to the right leg looking like a âTâ. Maintain this position as per your comfort level. During the final position you can breathe normally. Concentrate on the sense of balance and try to maintain this position for as long as you can. Repeat the same with the other leg, in which case the entire body weight is supported by the left foot alone.

1. Sit with the legs outstretched. Bend the knees and place the feet flat on the floor in front of the buttocks about half a meter apart. Holding the big toe slowly lean back, balancing on the coccyx. Straighten the legs and arms, raising them upward. 
 2. Steady the body, keeping the spine straight, then separate the legs as wide as possible, do not strain. 
 3. Hold the final position, keeping the gaze focused on a fixed point. 
 4. Bring the knees together at the center, bend the knees and lower the feet to the floor.

1. Squat on the floor with legs slightly apart. Place the hands on the floor and let the palms feel the floor. Raise the heels and balance yourself on the toes. 
 2. Slowly bend forward and shift the weight of the body to the palms. Lift yourself up using the palms. The elbows will be bent. Raise yourself up further till the hands are perpendicular to the ground. 
 3. Now the entire weight of the body will rest on the palms and the knees should touch the outside of the hands, just above the elbows. Retain the breath in the final position. Maintain this position for as long as possible. Your concentration should be on maintaining the balance of the body. 
 4. To release the pose, return to the initial squatting position and breathe normally. Repeat this as many times as you are comfortable.

1. Come on to hands and knees. Be sure that the wrists are directly beneath the shoulders. 
 2. Grasp the floor with the toes and straighten the knees, moving the shoulders forward and coming to balance on the palms. 
 3. Focus the gaze on a fixed point on the floor and few inches in front of you to ensure that the head, neck and spine all stay in one line.

1. Lie down on your back with feet apart, bend your knees and place your feet on the ground close to your body. Now bring your palms under your shoulders such that the fingers point towards the shoulders and the elbows are shoulder width apart. 
 2. Inhale and press your palms firmly into the floor. Lift your shoulders and elbow firmly into the floor. Your Feet should be pressed firmly into the floor. Inhale and lift your hips up. 
 3. The spine should be rolled up so that it may seem to resemble a semi circular arch or wheel. Straighten out your arms and legs as much as possible so that the hips and chest maybe pushed up. Hold this pose for at least 15-30 seconds. 
 4. To go back to original, bend your elbows to lower your head and shoulders to the floor. Then bend your knees and bring your spine and hips back to the ground and relax.

1. Lie on your back with your arms beside you, palms downwards. As you inhale, use your abdominal muscles to lift your feet off the floor, raising your legs vertically at a 90-degree angle. 
 2. Continue to breathe normally and supporting your hips and back with your hands, lift them off the ground. 
 3. Allow your legs to sweep in a 180-degree angle over your head till your toes touch the floor. Your back should be perpendicular to the floor. This may be difficult initially, but make an attempt for a few seconds. 
 4. Hold this pose and let your body relax more and more with each steady breath. After about a minute (a few seconds for beginners) of resting in this pose, you may gently bring your legs down on exhalation.

1.Assume a squatting posture and focus the gaze on a point straight.Keep the knees forward slightly so that the thighs are horizontal.2.Raise the heels and balance on the tip of the toes.Bring the right foot on top of the left thigh, resting the sole upward.The heel of the left foot presses against the perineum.3.Maintain the balance and place the palms together in front of the chest.Stay in this final position for some time.4.Then return to the starting position. Repeat the practice with the left foot on top of the right thigh.

1. Sit comfortably with your spine erect and shoulders relaxed. Keep a gentle smile on your face. Place your left hand on the left knee, palms open to the sky or in Chin Mudra (thumb and index finger gently touching at the tips). 
 2. Place the tip of the index finger and middle finger of the right hand in between the eyebrows, the ring finger and little finger on the left nostril, and the thumb on the right nostril. We will use the ring finger and little finger to open or close the left nostril and thumb for the right nostril. 
 3. Press your thumb down on the right nostril and breathe out gently through the left nostril. Now breathe in from the left nostril and then press the left nostril gently with the ring finger and little finger. Removing the right thumb from the right nostril, breathe out from the right. 
 4. Breathe in from the right nostril and exhale from the left. You have now completed one round of Nadi Shodhan pranayama. Continue inhaling and exhaling from alternate nostrils. Complete such rounds by alternately breathing through both the nostrils. After every exhalation, remember to breathe in from the same nostril from which you exhaled. Keep your eyes closed throughout and continue taking long, deep, smooth breaths without any force or effort.

1. Set comfortably in any meditative pose like Padmasana, Swastikasana etc. 
 2. Keep your both hands on knees.
Now bring your tongue all the way out and fold both sides of tongue like a tube or straw. 
 3. Take a long, deep inhalation through the tube in the tongue which is formed by folding the both sides of tongue. 
 4. After inhalation close your mouth and exhale with both nostrils.
1. Sit in any meditative pose in which you are comfortable. Keep your eyes close and try to touch the tongue upward.

1. Sit in a comfortable meditative pose. 
 2. Breathe normally and relax the whole body. Keep the mouth closed and the teeth apart. Plug both the ears with the index fingers and close the eyes. Some also use the thumb to close the ears. In this variation, the eyes are kept closed by using the middle finger. 
 3. Take a slow deep breath and fill the lungs fully. Then exhale slowly, making a continuous humming sound from the throat. The sound should reverberate in the head. 
 4. Feel the sound vibration in the head. Be aware of only the continuous drone that the sound produces. This drone is similar to the humming sound of the bee. This is one round. Start with 5 rounds and increase it as per your convenience.

1. Sit straight with your spine erect and cross your legs in front of you. 
 2. Take in a deep breath and exhale quickly and suddenly, making a puffing sound while you do it. Focus on exhaling forcefully and not on the inhalation. 
 3. When you exhale, draw your abdominal muscles inward simultaneously. Your abdomen should rise when you inhale and fold when you exhale. 
 4. Continue for 10 breaths and then take a break. Perform two more similar sets.

1. Sit in a comfortable position, place the hands on the knees, and hunch the shoulders up. 
 2. Inhale deeply and retain the breath. While holding the breath bend your head forward and try to touch the chin to the chest (JalandharaBandha). 
 3. Pull the abdomen in (as if with a vacuum in the chest, bringing it as far in as possible) then relax the abdomen. Repeat 10 times before taking a breath. 
 4. Inhale, relax the shoulders and release the lock. Gradually increase up to 50 repetitions.

1. One should decide where to do Tratak and keep it consistent from day to day. 
 2. If one should perform Tratak in oneâs room, he/she should sit 2.5 feet away from object (color dot on wall, candle, etc) which should be 2-3 inches below the line of vision. Stare with the naked eye on the object until eyes are no longer comfortable (watery eyes). 
 3. One should then close eyes and concentrate in between the eyebrows (Ajana charka). You can repeat again after relaxing eyes for half the time used the first time. 
 4. One should do a maximum of 3 times. After more practice, one can use a candle. One should do this kriya for 3 to 6 months. This kriya can ease the meditation process also.

1. Inhale deeply and hold the breath. Place the hands on the knees, lift the shoulders and tilt the body forward slightly, keeping the back straight. Press the chin firmly against the chest or between the collar bones so that the windpipe and oesophagus are firmly closed. 
 2. Concentrate on the Vishuddhi Chakra and hold the breath for as long as comfortable. 
 3. Raise the head and with a long exhalation return to the starting position. 
 4. Breathing normally remain in this position for some time.

1. Sit in Padmasana or Siddhasana with the spine straight. Place the palms on the knees, breathe normally and relax the whole body. Inhale deeply and then exhale fully. 
 2. Hold the breath outside. Slightly bend the shoulders and lean forward. Perform Jalandhara Bandha or the chin lock and press down the knees with the palm. 
 3. Contract the abdominal muscles and pull it inside and upwards. Feel as if there is a suction from a point just behind the sternum. This will enable the abdomen to go fully inside pressing all the abdominal organs against the back wall of the spine. 
 4. Hold the lock with the breath outside for as long as you are comfortable. One can start with few seconds and then gradually increase it to a minute over a period of time. Experts can hold the breath outside for even two minutes or more. To release the lock, first release the abdominal muscles. Then bring the shoulders back to normal position, release the chin lock and inhale. Wait till the breathing process comes back to normal. This process can be repeated as many times as you are comfortable.

1. Sit in comfortable meditative asana. Close the eyes and relax the whole body. 
 2. Be aware of the natural breathing. Focus the awareness on the perineal/vaginal region. 
 3. Contract this region by pulling up on the muscle of the pelvic floor and then relaxing them. 
 4. Continue to briefly contract and relax the perineal/vaginal region as rhythmically and evenly as possible. Breath normally throughout the practice.

1. While practicing the Jnana Mudra, make sure that you are sitting comfortably in the meditative pose, with your eyes closed. 
 2. Place your hands on your knees in such a way that the inner part of your wrists rest on the kneecap and the palm faces downwards. 
 3. Form a circle by bringing your index finger and thumb together. Make sure that the nail of the forefinger rests on the first thumb joint. 
 4. Keep the other three fingers extended.

1. Both the hands are used to practice this gesture. 
 2. Form a circle by joining your thumb and your forefinger. 
 3. Place the nail of your index finger against the soft pad of the thumb. 
 4. Extend the last three fingers of your hands, the palm-side facing upwards.

1. Make sure that you are sitting comfortably in the meditative pose, with your eyes closed. 
 2. In bhairava mudra, place the back of the right hand on the palm of the left hand. Both hands rest in the lap.

1. Make sure that you are sitting comfortably in the meditative pose, with your eyes closed. 
 2. In bhairavi mudra, place the back of the left hand on the palm of the right hand.

1. Sit in any comfortable meditation asana with the head and spine straight. 
 2. Place the tips of the index fingers at the root of the thumbs, as in chin and gyana mudras, and join the tips of the middle and ring fingers to the tips of the thumbs so they are placed side by side. The little finger remains straight. 
 3. Place the hands on the knees with the palms facing upward. Close the eyes and relax the whole body, keeping it motionless.

1. Sit in any comfortable meditation asana with the head and spine straight and the left hand in chin or gyana mudra. Close the eyes and relax the whole body. Open the eyes and raise the right hand in front of the face. 
 2. The elbow should point to the side of the body. Hold the hand horizontally, palm down with all the fingers together. The side of the thumb should be in contact with the top of the upper lip. 
 3. Focus the eyes on the tip of the little finger and gaze at it intently for a minute or so without blinking or flickering the eyes. 
 4. Try to maintain continuous awareness of the fingertip. After a minute or so remove the hand but continue to gaze into nothingness at the place where the little finger was in front of the face. Try not to blink.
1. This mudra is very easy to do. Just join together your tip of the middle finger to the tip of the thumb finger.

1. This is a technique of sensory isolation. The elbow are raised, shoulders backward. 
 2. Close the ears with the thumbs. 
 3. Close the eyes with second fingers resting on the eyelids. Close the nose with the third finger. Close the mouth by encircling it with the fourth and fifth fingers. 
 4. The focus is on light and sound, by adopting Maddya Drishti in the inner vision. Breathing is the link, the orchestrator.

1. Stand with shoulder width distance between legs while looking forward. 
 2. Lift your leg alternaly up and down. 
 3. Bend ur elbow swing your arms.

1. Stand straight keep your knee 90degree. 
 2.Move ur leg up and down alternative.

1. Hold the ends of the rope at arm's length in front of your hips with your hands shoulder-width apart. 
 2. Brace your core and begin alternately raising and lowering each arm explosively.

1. Run forward with short, quick steps, pumping your knees into the air and flexing your hip, knee and foot. 
 2. Keep your chest up, pump your arms and land on the balls of your feet.

1. Stand with your legs shoulder-width apart. 
 2. Your arms should be bent at your sides.
 
 3. Flex the right knee and kick your right heel up toward your glutes. 
 3. Bring the right foot back down. 
 4. As the right leg comes down, flex your left knee and kick your left foot up toward your glutes

1.Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you and arms at your sides. 
 2.  Place hands on the floor next to your hips, fingers pointing towards your feet. 
 3.  Lift your hips as high as you can, aiming for a straight line from chin to toes.

1.Rapid side steps. 
 2.  Take a step to left foot out to the side then bring the right foot to meet left. 
 3.  Stay on for toes and stay tall. 
 4.  Make sure you do the exercise in both directions.

1.Take squats position. 
 2. Hands Parellel to your body. 
 3. Drag your leg fast. 
 4. Move ahead slowly,with maintaining the posture.

1.Keep your upper body straight, with your shoulders back and relaxed and chin up (pick a point to stare at in front of you so you don't keep looking down). 
 2.  Always engage your core. 
 3. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle

1.Stand with your hands behind your head, and squat down keeping your torso upright and your head up. 
 2. This will be your starting position. 
 3.  Jump forward several feet, avoiding jumping unnecessarily high. 
 4. As your feet contact the ground, absorb the impact through your legs, and jump again.

1. Stand straight and tell someone to stand behind and put the theraband over your belly and resist it . 
 2. And you pull the opposite side.

1.Start in a push-up position with the hands shoulder-width apart and the legs straight out directly behind the body about hip-width apart. 
 2.  Push the toes of the left foot into the floor and squeeze the left thigh and glute while moving the right knee forward to the outside of the right elbow.

1. Keep two cone on 30m distance . 
 2. run and touch and come to previous cone and repeat.

1.Perform a quarter squat into a forward jump over the line. 
 2. Land in a deep squat position with knees in line with feet and behind toes. 
 3. Hold squat for 2 seconds.

1. Start with running action with ligfting your leg high 
Extend lower leg 
 2. Accelerate leg down with an eccentric contraction of hamstring 
 3. Repeat with opposite leg in skipping fashion

1. Run on toes. 
 2. Hit your leg straight. 
 3. Keep your knee straight.

1.Get into a squat position, knees at roughly a 45-degree angle, and walk sideways. 
 2. Take 5 to 10 steps to the left, then right, keeping your knees bent and maintaining resistance throughout. Repeat.

1. Lie down on your abdomen and point your feet behind you. 
 2. Bring your hand next your glutes. 
 3.  Start movemt as you do in the  swimming pool.

1.Stand tall with your feet together and your hands at your sides. 
 2.  Quickly raise your arms above your head while jumping your feet out to the sides. 
 3. Immediately reverse the movement to jump back to the standing position.

1. Stand straight bend your one leg. 
 2. now start jumping from the other leg and do the recommended repition.
1. Run with 50% off effort for  30m

1. Stand lateral be on ur toes. 
 2. Start running with lateraly. 
 3. Move your hand up and down sideways.

1. Run backward with short, quick steps, reaching the heel of your foot to your glutes, extending your leg behind your body. 
 2. Keep your chest up, pump your arms and land on the balls of your feet.

1.Set up a row of hurdles or other small barriers, placing them a few feet apart. 
 2. Stand in front of the first hurdle with your feet shoulder width apart. 
 3. This will be your starting position. 
 4. Begin by jumping with both feet over the first hurdle, swinging both arms as you jump.

1.Begin with 3 to 5 hurdles spaced at regular hurdle distance. 
 2. Use a 30" height or lower for beginning hurdlers. 
 3. Theathlete approaches the hurdles so that the lead leg will go over the side of the hurdle and the trail leg will be in the open lane adjacent to the hurdle. 
 4.  The knee is then driven at the hurdle.

1.Start by standing in front of a set of stairs in a squat position. 
 2. Jump with two feet bringing your knees to your chest while jumping to the stairs in front of you.
1. Stand straight on single leg and jump on each strair from single leg.

1. Stand straight lift your leg up and jump with single leg. 
 2. Do alternate leg.

1. Start from sitting in an erect and upright posture looking straight ahead (neutral position) and slowly turn your head as if you are trying to look over your shoulder. 
 2. Turn only as far as you comfortably can. 
 3. When you feel tightness or pulling on the opposite side, or compression and pinching on the side you're turning toward, stop and hold that position for three to five seconds, then slowly come back to the neutral position.

1. Stand spread your leg wide. 
 2.  touch your toe alternatly. 
 3. maintain your leg horizontal.
1. Stand straight hands at aside start moving up and down sideway.

1. Place your feet on the band; distance between the feet should be shoulder width. Grip the handles in an overhand grip and raise your hands upto your shoulders. 
 2. Squat down to a level where the thigh is parallel to the floor or even below. 
 3. Come back up explosively with hands still on the shoulders. 
 4. Go down and repeat. 
 5. Remember to keep the core muscles engaged throughout the movement.

displayName: Toe Raise With Resistance Band And Thera Band
description:
1. Tie the band to an anchor like the leg of a bed or exercise machine and wrap the other end of the loop on top of your feet. 
 2. Sit afar such that the band is stretched to form a slight tension on your feet. 
 3. Flex your feet towards your knees such that you feel some tension in your shins. 
 4. Release and bring the feet to natural position. 
 5. Repeat the form and take care of having controlled movements

1. Tie the band to an anchor like the leg of a bed or exercise machine and wrap the other end of the loop at the ankle of your right leg. 
 2. Walk away from the anchor such that some tension forms on your right leg. 
 3. Stand with the feet apart with hip width distance. 
 4. Shift your weight on the left leg and lift the right leg from the floor. 
 5. Extend your leg such that the knee straightens out completely. 
 6. Bring back the leg slowly and extend again 6. Repeat the form and take care of having controlled movements. 
 7. After one set, switch sides. 
 8. Remember to keep your core muscles engaged throughout the repetitions.

displayName: Prone Hamstrings Curl With Resistance Band
description:
1. Tie the band to an anchor like the leg of a bed or exercise machine and wrap the other end of the loop at the ankle of your right leg. 
 2. Lie on your belly and move away from the anchor to create some tension. 
 3. Tighten your core muscles and bend your knees bring your heels towards your glutes as much as possible. 
 4. Bring the leg back down slowly and repeat the movement. 
 5. After one set, switch sides. 
 6. Remember to keep your core muscles engaged through all the repetitions.

displayName: Squat And Overhead Press With Resistance Band
description:
1. Place your feet on the band; distance between the feet should be shoulder width. Grip the handles in an overhand grip and raise your hands upto your shoulders. 
 2. Squat down to a level where the thigh is parallel to the floor or even below. 
 3. Come back up explosively with the hands raised overhead. 
 4. Go down and repeat. 
 5. Remember to keep the core muscles engaged throughout the movement.

displayName: Reverse Lunge And Rows With Resistance Band
description:
1. Tie the band to an anchor like a pole or an exercise machine; tie it at a height that is slightly below your chest level. 
 2. Stand facing the band and gripping the loops. 
 3. Engage your core muscles, take a your left leg back in a large step and do a reverse lunge. 
 4. Then release the band carfully, and stand; while coming up, engage your core muscles and do a powerfull rowing, squeezing your back muscles. 
 5. Repeat the form and after completing one set, switch sides.

displayName: Squat And Rows With Resistance Band
description:
1. Tie the band to an anchor like a pole or an exercise machine; tie it at a height that is slightly below your chest level. 
 2. Stand facing the band and gripping the loops. 
 3. Engage your core muscles, do a squat going down as much as possible. 
 4. Come slowly up and then, do a powerful rowing, squeezing your back muscles. 
 5. Repeat the movement and remember to keep your core muscles engaged through all the repetitions.

displayName: Glute Back Kicks With Resistance Band
description:
1. Take the handles of the band in your hands and do down on all your fours. 
 2. Loop the middle portion of the band on the arch of your right foot. 
 3. Engage your core muscles, keep your back neutral and give a powerful but, controlled kick with your right leg, stretching out the leg as much as possible. 
 4. Hold for a moment and then bring the leg back slowly. 
 5. After one set, switch sides.

displayName: Lying Side Leg Raise With Resistance Band And Thera Band
description:
1. Lie down on your left side. 
 2. String a resistance loop around and a little above your ankles. 
 3. Engage your core and upper body muscles, squeeze your glutes and lift up your right leg straight in the air. 
 4. Hold up there for a moment and bring your leg down slowly. 
 5. Repeat the form and after one set, switch sides.

1. String a resistance loop around and slightly above your ankles. 
 2. Take a stance of shoulder width distance to create tension on the band. 
 3. Lower your body into a partial squat position and start walking sideways. 
 4. While walking, move the legs such a way that the tension on the band is maintained. 
 5. Walk a distance of 7-10 steps on one side before switching on to the other side.

displayName: Seated Horizontal Rows With Resistance Band
description:
1. Sit down with your legs fully extended. 
 2. Anchor the centre part of the band on the sole of your feet. 
 3. Grip the handles of the band with hands facing outside the knees. 
 4. Engage your core muscles, keep an upright back, elbows slightly bent and pull the hands back such that you form a 90 degree at the elbow joint. 
 5. While pulling, pull the bands towards your hips and take the elbows till behind, such that you feel a squeeze in your back muscles. 
 6. Maintain an engaged core and upright back through all the repetitions.

displayName: Bent Over Rows With Resistance Band
description:
1. Stand at the centre of the band, distance between the feet should be shoulder width. 
 2. Bend your knees slightly, hinge at the waist and jutt out your hips from the back (like the body position that forms when you are about to sit on a chair). 
 3. With the elbows slightly bent, pull the band towards your hips and take the elbows till behind such that you feel a squeeze in your back muscles. 
 4. Maintain an engaged core and upright back through all the repetitions.

displayName: Kneeling Ab Crunch With Resistance Band
description:
1. Anchor the band at the center at a height on a door or pole. 
 2. Grip both the sides of the resistance bands in both the hands. 
 3. Hold the hands near to your forehead and bend down with your head going towards the ground. 
 4. While rising up, keep your back bent slightly and hands held at forehead only. 
 5. Repeat with this form till the last repetition.

displayName: Pull And Crunch With Resistance Band
description:
1. Anchor the band around a door or pole. 
 2. Lie on your back with legs bent, pulling the band away from the anchor for creating tension. 
 3. Grip the handles in front of your chin; this is your start position. 
 4. Crunch your upper body and at the same time push your hand forward such that you are reaching till your knees. 
 5. Make sure that you are not moving your head; tuck your chin to your chest.

1. Anchor the band to a door or pole, at chest level. 
 2. Grip both the handles of the band together in both your hands and stand side ways, far enough from the anchor to create tension in the band. 
 3. Keep your back upright and core muscles engaged. 
 4. Twist your torso (only at your waist) to the opposite till you feel a nice squeeze in your side abs. 
 5. Hold for a moment, return to original position and repeat to complete the set.

displayName: Band Chest Press With Resistance Band
description:
1. Loop the band around a pole, a pillar or door, at chest level. 
 2. Face away from the band and move forward pulling the band, to create some tension. 
 3. Take position; leaning your torso slightly forward, keep your arms at chest level. 
 4. Push forward your hands explosively and hold for a moment. Then slowly come back and repeat.

displayName: Band Push Up With Thera Band
description:
1. Adjust the band at the top of your back and grip the ends in the hands in front for you. The band should rest on your triceps. 
 2. Make sure the band is tight enough to create the required tension. 
 3. Start doing the push up; go down and while coming up, come up explosively. 
 4. Keep your core muscles engaged throughout the repetitions for generating the explosive force while coming up.

1. Stand on the center of the band, hold the handles in an overhead grip; cross your hands over the thighs. 
 2. Keep your back upright and your core muscles engaged. 
 3. Pull the bands up to your neck; the elbows must go a bit higher than the shoulder level. 
 4. Hold for a moment and slowly brings your hands down

1. Shorten the band sufficiently to create good tension and stand on it with hip width stance. 
 2. Hold the handles in a neutral grip at the side of your body. 
 3. Retract and raise your shoulders up to your neck. 
 4. Hold for a moment and release slowly

1. Stand on the centre of the band with hip width stance and hold the handles in a neutral grip at the side of your body. 
 2. Keep your arms straight; elbows shy of lockout. 
 3. Raise your arms laterally up till shoulder level to form a 'T' shape. 
 4. Hold it up for a moment and slowly bring down. 
 5. Make sure in every repetition, the back is upright and core muscles are engaged.

1. Take your right foot forward and stand with it on the centre of the band. 
 2. Grip the handles in an overhead grip on your thighs. 
 3. Rise your arms straight up till shoulder level. 
 4. Hold it up for a moment and slowly bring down. 
 5. Make sure in every repetition, the back is upright and core muscles are engaged.

displayName: Standing Overhead Press With Resistance Band
description:
1. Stand on the band with a shoulder width stance. 
 2. Hold the handles in an overhead grip and raise your hands straight up over your head, check for good tightness in the band for creating tension. 
 3. Keep your back upright and core muscles engaged. 
 4. Lower your hands to the level of your shoulders and push up explosively; hold for a moment and get hands down slowly. 
 5. Repeat to complete the set.

1. Stand on the band with a hip width stance and hold the handles with an underhand grip. 
 2. Let the band be stretched to create some tension. 
 3. Lift your forearms to the body, flexing at the elbow joint and squeeze your biceps. 
 4. Hold for a moment and slowly bring your hands down.

1. Take your foot back and stand on the band with that foot. 
 2. Grip the handle in one arm and raise that arm straight above your head. Let the band be tight enough to create some tension. 
 3. Keep your back upright and your core muscles engaged. 
 4. Without bending your arms at the shoulder, bend your arem at the elbow such that your forearm forms a 90 degree angle at the elbow joint.
