 5. Feel a tight contraction in the triceps, hold it for a moment and put your arm up. 
 6. Repeat to complete one set and then switch to the other arm.

1. Lie prone on floor with hands slightly wider than shoulder width. 
 2. Bend knees and raise body up off floor by extending arms with body straight. 
 3. Keeping body straight and knees bent, lower body to floor by bending arms. 
 4. Push body up until arms are extended, Repeat.

1. Place hands on floor, slightly wider than shoulder width. 
 2. On forefeet, position one leg forward bent under body and extend other leg back. 
 3. While holding upper body in place, alternate leg positions by pushing hips up while immediately extending forward leg back and pulling rear leg forward under body, landing on both forefeet simultaneously.

1. Squat down and jump up as high as possible. 
 2. Reach up with one or both hands and hit flag. 
 3. Upon landing, immediately jump up again and attempt to reach higher.

1. Stand in front of a secured box or platform. 
 1. Jump onto box and immediately back down to same position. Immediately repeat.

1. Instead of standing back up, sink into thatÂ squatÂ and holdÂ it. 
 2. Keep all of the weight in your heels, while driving the knees and hips open. 
 3. Be sure to maintain and upright body position with your chest up, shoulders back and down, and core engaged.

1. Place a set of ankle weights on your right and left ankles. 
 2. Stand behind a chair with your back straight and place one or both of your hands on the back of a chair. 
 3. Keep your knees completely in line with your hips and maintain this position. 
 4. Raise your foot as far as possible for maximum contraction.

displayName: One Leg Body weight Calf Raise
description:
1. Position toes and balls of feet on calf block or elevation with heels and arches extending off. 
 2. Place hand or hands on support for balance. 
 3. Lift one leg to rear by bending knee. 
 4. Raise heel by extending ankle as high as possible. 
 5. Lower heel by bending ankle until calf is stretched. Repeat.

1. Lie on your front with your forehead resting on your hands. 
 2. Your legs should be straight out on the floor. 
 3. Inhale to prepare and as you exhale set your core. 
 4. While keeping your back straight float one leg up off the ground and hold for a breath. 
 5. Bring the leg down to the mat and repeat with the opposite leg.

1. Lie face down legs straight arms extended in front of your head. 
 2. Raise your right arm and left leg as high as is comfortable. 
 3. Return to the start position, switch sides and repeat.

1. Assume the starting position with legs and feet wide, about 2 feet from the wall. One arm should be straight out in front of you, palm on the wall, at about shoulder level and in line with the center of your body. The other arm should be around your back. 
 2. Bend your elbow and begin to lean your body toward the wall as far as you can go. Ensure that your back stays straight and your hips donât sag. Try to keep your body weight evenly distributed instead of leaning to the side you are pushing from. 
 3. Push back to the starting position and complete as many reps as possible. 
 4. Switch arms and repeat.

1. Start with feet close togehter in a an athletic postion, then squat down. 
 2. Pushing off both feet evenly, jump to the side in a small motion.

1. With your right foot slightly off the ground, balance on your left foot. 
 2. Hop back and forth over an imaginary line laterally for 30 seconds. 
 3. Repeat the same motion, balancing on your right foot.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. Bend knees and come up onto the balls of your feet. 
 2. Jump forward and backward in a quick, small movement.Â

1. Stand with your feet and knees together. 
 2. Take a large step with your right foot to the right side and lunge toward the floor. 
 3. Make sure your right knee does not extend past your toes and keep your left leg relatively straight.
4)Push off through your right foot to return to the start to complete one.

1. Complete a traditional forward lunge, then take a big step to the right and lunge again. 
 2. Finish off the semicircle with a backwards lunge, then return to standing. 
 3. And all thatâs one rep! Aim for suggested reps and then switch legs.

1. Position heels on forward edge of calf block or platform. 
 2. Grasp support with other hand for balance. 
 3. Pull forefoot of both feet up toward body as far as possible. 
 4. Return by extending feet until toes are pointed downward. 'Repeat'.

1. Begin on your hands and knees. 
 2. Lift your knees off the ground, balancing on your toes and keeping your hips low. 
 3. Move one hand and the opposite knee forward simultaneously to pedal yourself forward.

1. Sit with your legs bent and slightly spread, feet on the ground. 
 2. Place your hands on the ground behind you, fingertips facing forward. 
 3. Lift your hips & butt off the ground, holding yourself up on your hands and feet. 
 4. Pedal yourself forward, backward, and/or side to side.

1. Begin in a plank position with your shoulders over your wrists, your feet together, and your body in a straight line. 
 2. Bend your left arm so that it is now in forearm plank position. 
 3. Then bend your right arm so you are in a full forearm plank position. 
 4. Lift your left hand and place it on the mat directly below your shoulder as you push through your palm to lift yourself. 
 5. As you reach the top, place your right palm on the floor under your right shoulder and push back into a full plank.  Repeat, leading with the right arm.

1). Begin standing with the arms extended overhead. 
 2. Bend the knees and, in a controlled motion, lower your tush all the way to the floor. 
 3. Roll onto your back, drawing your knees toward your face. 
 4. Use momentum to kick forward, landing on the feet. 
 5. Rise to stand, and do an explosive jump straight up, getting as much height as you can. 6)Remember to keep your elbows bent and palms off the floor while you rise so you're using your core muscles and not your hands to help you get up.
1. Stand with both feet hip apart, rais your toe and be on heel and start walking.

1. Standing with the knees slightly bent. 
 2. Jump up as high as possible and bring the knees in toward the chest while extending the arms straight out. 
 3. Land with the knees slightly bent and quickly jump (on it) again.

1. Beginning on all fours with the core engaged. 
 2. Slowly walk the hands forward, staying on the toes but not moving them forward. 
 3. Next, gradually walk the hands backwards to the starting position, maintain stability and balance.

1. Start in a plank position on your forearms with your feet shoulder width apart and your lower back flat. 
 2.Press your body up to a push-up position and then lower yourself back down into the plank. 
 3. Do all the reps on one side or alternate sides for the recommended number of reps.

1. Slowly slide your back down a wall until the thighs are parallel to the ground. 
 2. Make sure the knees are directly above the ankles and keep the back straight. 
 3. Go for 30-60 seconds per set.

1. Take a big step forward, and make sure you are in a stable position. 
 2. Grab dumbbells in your hands with the palms facing in, and hold them at arm's length. 
 3. Bend slightly forward so your back forms a straight line with your back leg. 
 4. Raise the dumbbells with your elbows close to your sides.

1. When lunging, step the left leg back behind the right, bending the knees and lowering the hips until the right thigh is almost parallel to the floor. 
 2. Remember to keep the torso upright and the hips square. 
 3. Return back to startin position and do it with another side.

1. Grab a dumbbell and lie sideways on a 30 degree incline bench.  
 2. Raise your arm to complete the motion just like a normal Side Lateral Raise.

1. Attach a rope to a pulley station set at about chest level.  
 2. Grasp both ends of the rope with a pronated (overhand) grip.  
 3. Step back so you're supporting the weight with arms completely outstretched and assume a staggered (one foot forward) stance. Bend the knees slightly for a stable base.  
 4. Retract the scapulae and pull the center of the rope slightly up towards the face. A good cue is to think about pulling the ends of the rope apart, not just pulling back.  
 5. As you near your face, externally rotate so your knuckles are facing the ceiling.  
 6. Hold for one second at the top position and slowly lower.

1.Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight. 
 2. Stand directly in between the uprights. Grasp the cables and hold them at shoulder height, palms facing forward. This will be your starting position. 
 3. Keeping your head and chest up, extend through the elbow to press the handles directly over head. 
 4. After pausing at the top, return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Start by standing to the right side of a low pulley row. Use your left hand to come across the body and grab a single handle attached to the low pulley with a pronated grip (palms facing down). Rest your arm in front of you. Your right hand should grab the machine for better support and balance. 
 2. Make sure that your back is erect and your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position. 
 3. Begin to use the left hand and come across your body out until it is elevated to shoulder height while exhaling.  
 4. Feel the contraction at the top for a second and begin to slowly lower the handle back down to the original starting position while inhaling. 
 5. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.  
 6. Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

1.Position a cable at the lowest position possible and attach a straight bar. 
 2.Reach down and grab the handle with a pronated grip and stand up with the arms straight. 
 3. Take a deep breath then pull the handle high directly up the front of your body by driving your elbows high.
Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position under control. 
 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1.Take a dumbbell in each hand and lay back onto a flat bench. Your feet should be flat on the floor and your shoulder blades retracted. 
 2. Maintaining a neutral grip, palms facing each other, begin with your arms extended directly above you, perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. 
 3. Begin the movement by flexing the elbow, lowering the upper arms to the side. Descend until the dumbbells are to your torso. 
 4. Pause, then extend the elbow and return to the starting position.

1. Start off by laying flat on your back on a decline bench, feet on the rested underneath the pads and hands holding dumbbells in a underhand reverse grip at the sides of your chest. 
 2. Slowly push the dumbbells straight up above your chest, squeezing your pecs and hold for a count. 
 3. Return back to the starting position. 
 4. Repeat for as many reps and sets as desired.

1. Set the handle to the lowest position on Cable machine. 
 2. Now like the Cable Crossover, bring the handles at level with your eyes.  
 3. Contract the chest at the end of the motion.

1. Lie down on a flat bench with a plate pinched between your hands.  
 2. From the bottom position, extend your arms holding the plate directly above your chest.  
 4. Squeeze at the top and repeat.

1. Lie down on a flat/Inclined bench with a pair of dumbbell held with a Neutral grip.  
 2. Starting from the bottom, press the dumbbells together straight above your chest.  
 3. Squeeze at the top, repeat.

1. Same as Cable Crossover, but finish the movement at three different positions. 
 2. First repetition finishes at the top, second at the center and third will be finished very low near the waist.  
 3. All three portions of the chest(Upper, Middle and Lower) will be activated simultaneously.

1.Position a flat bench between two low pulleys so that when you are laying on it, your chest will be lined up with the cable pulleys.  
 2. Lay flat on the bench and keep your feet on the ground.  
 3. Have someone hand you the handles on each hand. You will grab each single handle attachment with a palms up grip.  
 4. Extend your arms by your side with a slight bend on your elbows.  
 5. Now start lifting the arms in a semi-circle motion directly in front of you by pulling the cables together until both hands meet at the top of the movement. Squeeze your chest as you perform this motion and breathe out during this movement. Also, hold the contraction for a second at the top.  
 6. Slowly come back to the starting position.  
 7. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

1.To get yourself into the starting position, set the pulleys at the floor level.  
 2. Place an incline bench in between the pulleys, select a weight on each one and grab a pulley on each hand.  
 3. With a handle on each hand, lie on the incline bench and bring your hands together at arms length in front of your face.  
 4. With a slight bend of your elbows, lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.  
 5. Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and exhale. Hold the contracted position for a second.  
 6.Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

1. Set the bench at declined position at the middle of the cable machine.  
 2. Grab the handles,set at the lowest postion of Cable machine.  
 3. Bring the handles above the chest to mimic Dumbbell flyes. Finish the repetition and repeat.

1. With the D-Handle fixed on the Lat Pulldown machine, grab it and sit on the bench facing the machine.  
 2. Pull the handle using your palms just as a hook.  
 3. Finish at the same point as a contemporary lat pulldown, repeat.

1. With two D-Bar or one V-Bar attached to the lat pulldown machine,  
 2. sit on the bench.  
 3. Pull the bar down till your upper chest and contract your back.  
 4. Finish the repetition and repeat.

1. Place the bar of Smith Machine on the lowest postion.  
 2. Stand with one leg on each side.  
 3. Place a V-Bar under the bar.  
 4. Bend down keeping your lower back straight and pull the bar towards your chest.  
 5. Contract at the finishing position and repeat.

1. Place the bar of Smith Machine on the lowest postion.  
 2. Stand on one side and bend down keeping your back straight.  
 3. Grab the bar and pull towards yourself as in a Dumbbell One Arm Row.  
 4. Contract at the finishing position and repeat.

1. Grab a dumbbell and lie down across a bench.  
 2. Hold the dumbbell by the plate with both hands.  
 3. Bring the weight down behind your head keeping your arms straight.  
 4. Feel the stretch in your back at the finishing position and bring the dumbbell back to top of your chest.  
 5. Repeat.

1. Fix the cable at level with your waist.  
 2. Without any handle attached, grab the cable, bend down keeping your back straight.  
 3. Keeping the elbow close to the torso, move your lower arm contracting at the finish position.  
 4. Repeat

1.Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart and your toes slightly turned out.  
 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand in front of your hips.  
 3.Push your hips back and squat down, keeping your chest up and knees out.  
 4.Bring the weights down to the floor in between your legs.

1. Stand with feet closer than shoulder width and toes pointing straight.  
 2.Push your hips back and squat down keeping your chest up.  
 3. Stand back up and repeat.

1. Lie down across a bench with feet shoulder width apart.  
 2. Place a barbell on your waist.  
 3. Keeping feet intact, move your hip upwards raising the barbell.  
 4. Hold the contraction for a second and bring your hip down again. Repeat.

1. Lie down on Leg Press Machine and instead of placing both your legs, just place one leg at a time.  
 2. Press the weights, hold for a second at the top position and repeat.

1. Lie down on Leg Press Machine and instead of placing both your toes, just place one toe at a time.  
 2. Press with your toe, hold the contraction for a second at the top position and repeat.

1. Place a light dumbbell on the floor, standing on end. Choose a lighter dumbbell than you think youâll need at first, until youâre comfortable with the exercise.  
 2. Lie down on the floor, on your stomach, with your legs straight and feet close to the dumbbell. Place your feet on either side of the dumbbell handle.  
 3. Squeeze the dumbbell between your feet and bend your knees to lift it off the floor. The top weight on the dumbbell will rest on the bottom of your feet.  
 4. Bend your knees slowly up toward your butt, keeping the bottoms of your feet facing the ceiling throughout the movement. Slowly lower the weight back down. Stop just before the dumbbell touches the floor; repeat.  
 5. Perform the exercise lying on a flat bench if you'd like more of a challenge at the bottom of the movement; the bench allows you to straighten your legs completely.

1.Begin lying on your back with your hands extended above you toward the ceiling.  
 2. Bring your feet, knees, and hips up to 90 degrees.  
 3. Exhale hard to bring your ribcage down and flatten your back onto the floor, rotating your pelvis up and squeezing your glutes. Hold this position throughout the movement. This will be your starting position.  
 4. Initiate the exercise by extending one leg, straightening the knee and hip to bring the leg just above the ground.
Maintain the position of your lumbar and pelvis as you perform the movement, as your back is going to want to arch.  
 5. Stay tight and return the working leg to the starting position.  
 6. Repeat on the opposite side, alternating until the set is complete.

1. Sit down at the edge of a flat bench that has a dumbbell right in front of it.  
 2. Use the right arm to pick it up the dumbbell and place the back of that upper arm on top of your inner right thigh.  
 3. Rotate the palm of the hand until it is facing forward away from your thigh. Your arm should be extended at arms length and the dumbbell should be above the floor. This will be your starting position.  
 4. While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Squeeze the biceps and hold the contracted position for a second.  
 5. Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in. Avoid swinging motions at any time.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions. Then repeat the movement with the left arm.

1.Set up for the cable concentration curl by grabbing a flat bench and positioning it in front of a low pulley cable machine.  
 2. Attach a straight bar to the low pulley cable and select the weight you want to use on the stack.  
 3. Sit on the end of the bench with your feet at around shoulder width apart.  
 4.Grasp the bar with an underhand grip.  
 5. Rest your elbows on the inner part of the knee. Hold your elbows in place by pushing out with your elbows and in with your knees. This should lock them in throughout the set.  
 6. Take the slack off the cable so the tension is on the biceps. This is the starting position.  
 7. Slowly curl the bar up as far as possible.  
 8. Pause and squeeze the biceps, and then slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.
Repeat for desired reps.

1. Sit in Padmasana and close the eyes. Breathing normally. Hold the wrist behind the back with the other Hand. Inhale deeply.  
 2. While exhaling,bend forward, keeping the spine straight.Bring the forehead to the floor or as closeas is comfortable.Relax the whole body in the finak position,breathing slowly and deeply.  
 3 . Be aware of the pressure of the heels on the abdomen. Stay in the final position for as long as is comfortable.Do not strain the back,ankles,knees or thighs by forcing the bodyinto the posture. Repeat the pose with the legs crossed the other way round.

1.Sit in Pasmasana and relax the whole body. Carefully bend backward,supporting the body with the arms and elbows.Lift the chest slightly , take the head back and lower the crown ofbthe head to the floor.  
 2. Hold the big toes and rest the elbows on the floor. Adjust the position of the head so that the maximum arch of the back is attained.  
 3. Relax the arms and the whole body,allowing the head,buttocks and legs to support the weight of the body. Close the eyes and breath slowly and deeply.  
 4.Return to the starting position,reversing the order of movements. Repeat the asana,with the legs crossed the other way.

1. Assume marjari-asana.Turn the toes under. Place the crown of the head on the floor between the hands.  
 2. Balancing on the head and feet, straighten the knees and raise the buttocks. Bring the heels together and separate the toes.  
 3. Slowly raise the arms and interlock the fingers behind the back. Come up onto the toes as high as possible. Hold this final pose for some time.  
  4. Come up onto the toes as high as possible. Hold this final pose for some time. Slowly return to marjari-asana and then lower into shashankasana for a few moments.

1. Relax in the standing position with feet together. Raise the arms in front of the body over the head.  
 2. Bend forward from the hips, transferring the weight to the right foot, and touch the toes of the right foot with both hands . Simultaneously, slowly stretch the left leg behind, raising it as high as is comfortableand bring the forehead towards the right knee.  
 3. Keep both legs straight. To release, lower the leg and return to the upright position,keeping the arms straight as they are raised above the head. Then lower the arms and relax in the final position. Repeat the practice on the other side.

1. Sit with the legs outstretched. Separate the feet as wide apart as possible. Bend the knees slightly, keeping the heels on the floor. Lean forward from the hips and place the hands under the knees, palms facing down.  
 2. Slowly slide the arms under the legs and bring it backward until the elbows lie near the back of the knees. Straighten the legs as best as possible, move the body forward until the forehead or chin touches the floor between the legs.  
 3. Fold the arms around the back and interlock the fingers by wrapping over the buttocks. Close the eyes, relax the whole body and breathe slowly and deeply.  
  4. Stay in this final position for some time. Then return to the starting position. Slowly release the hands, lower the legs and the arms from the legs.

1. Kneel on the floor with the ankles together,toes flat on the floor and trunk upright. Stretch the right leg sideways to the right, Keeping it in line with the trunk and the left knee.  
  2. Turn the right toes in slightly and rest the sole of the right foot on the ground. Raise the arms sideways at shoulder level so that they form one straight line.  
 3. Move the trunk and right arm towards the extended leg. Rest the right forearm and wrist on the right shin and ankle respectively, with the right palm facing upward. The right ear will then rest on the right upper arm.  
 4. Move the left  arm over the head and place the left palm on top of the right palm. This is the final position. Repeat the pose on the other side for an equal length of time.

1. Sit in any meditative asana. The fingers can assume Jnana mudra or Chin mudra and the palms can rest on the knees.  
 2. Shambhavi mudra is nothing but gazing at the eyebrow center. With our eyes we cannot actually see the place where the two eyebrows meet. But an attempt is made to focus the vision between the eyebrows. Roll both the eyes upwards and try to gaze at the eyebrow center.  
 3. When you do this, you will be able to see the two eyebrows as two curved lines meeting at the center. It forms a kind of V-shaped line with a dip at the center. Concentrate the eyes on this dip in the lower center region of the V-shaped line. 
 4. Maintain this position for as long as you can. Initially, the eye muscles will start to pain after few seconds or within minutes. Relax the eyes and bring it back to the normal position. Rest for some time and try again. With practice one can maintain this gaze for longer period of time. Breathe normally during the practice. As you proceed with the meditation technique, your breath will slow down and become more subtle.

1.Sit with the legs stretched out in front of the body and the feet slightly apart.Bend forward and grasp the big toe of the right leg with the right hand and grasp the big toe of left leg with the left hand keeping the head facing forward. 
 2. Now inhale slowly to expand the abdominal muscles to their fullest extent. Hold the breath inside without straining the lungs in any way. Exhale slowly while relaxing the abdomen.  
 3. Repeat the breathing up to 10 times. Then release the toes and return to the starting position. This is 1 round. Practise 3 to 5 rounds.
Zumba involves dance and aerobic movements performed to energetic music. Zumba is a high calorie burn workout which you will enjoy too while doing.

Aerobics is a form of physical exercise that combines rhythmic aerobic exercise with stretching and strength training routines. Step aerobics is a form of aerobic exercise using of an elevated platform (the step).
Kickboxing is a combat sports based on kicking and punching. Kickboxing can Boost Confidence Levels,Improved Coordination and Burn Mega Calories.

Working out at a regular gym can be monotonous, and finding the motivation to push yourself can be tedious and difficult but in MMA fitness centre, you have an instructor and classmates pushing you along. Because youâre building self-defense skills as you go, you have something to think about as you exercise.

Playing table tennis can improve mind-body coordination and it stimulates mental alertness, concentration and tactical strategy.
Develops mental acuity. ...
Improves reflexes. ...

1. Pranamasana - Stand straight , keep feets together and join palms for prayer.  
 2. Hast uttanasana- Inhale and Bend back with raised arms.  
 3. Padahastasana - Exhale,contract stomach and bend forward to place palms across feets.  
 4. Ashwasanchalanasa - Inhale and stretch right leg back comfortably as much possible keeping left foot between palms.  
 5. Parvatasana - Exhale and join both legs back together . Raise buttocks up and lower the head between arms upto body forms triangle shape .  
 6. Ashtanga Namaskara - Inhale , lower the body parallel to the floor. Exhale, Raise hip & abdomen up except chin, Both palms, chest, both knees, both feets (toes).  
 7. Bhujangasana- Inhale,Slowly raise your trunk & head with the support of the palms by bending back up to the abdomen.  
 8. Parvatasana - Exhale and join both legs back together . Raise buttocks up and lower the head between arms upto body forms triangle shape .  
 9. Ashwasanchalanasa - Inhale, bring right leg front in between palms by keeping left foot back .  
 10. Padahastasana- Exhale, bring left foot next to right by keeping knee straight and palms on the floor.  
 11. Hast uttanasana- Inhale and Bend back with raised arms.  
 12. Pranamasana - Stand straight , keep feets together and join palms for prayer.  
 13.Same repeat with left leg.

1.Sit on your knees with your feet together and buttocks resting on your heels.  
 2.Separate your knees about the width of your hips. Place your hands on your thighs, palms down. (This is the vajra-asana or Thunderbolt Pose). Inhale deeply, then exhale as you bring your chest between your knees while swinging your arms forward then slowly swing them backward.  
 3.Place the soles of the feet together, clasp the hands over the feet interlocking the fingers pulling the feet closer and placing the heels against the perineum. The outer edge and small toe of each foot should touch the floor.  
 4.Breath gently through your nostrils as you hold the posture. Hold for about one to two minutes. Then return to an upright kneeling position with your back straight and your hands on your thighs. Repeat the posture at least one more time.

1.Stand straight with your legs hip-distance apart and arms on your sideNow, spread your legs wide-apart.  
 2.Turn your right feet out to face the right side of the mat.  
 3.The other feet will turn inward to make a 45 degree angle.  
 4. Do not twist your body; keep it in the center, facing the front.  
 5. Go forward on your right knee making a 90 degree angle; make sure your knee doesn't cross over the toe. Turn your neck right, look right. Let the other leg stretch properly.  
 6.Bring your arms parallel to the floor, stretched wide apart. Hold for 10 seconds and repeat on the other side.

1.Stand straight with your legs hip-distance apart and arms on your sides.Now, spread your legs wide-apart.  
 2.Turn your right feet out to face the left side of the mat.  
 3.The other feet will turn inward to make a 45 Degree angle,Twist your body to left completely.Twist your body right side, raise your hands paralle to floor.  
 4.Go forward on your left knee making a 90 Degree angle; make sure that your knee doesn't cross over the toe.Let the other leg stretch properly.

1.Starting in a High Lunge with your right foot forward, hips are square to the front of the mat, arms are either side of your ears with the hands shoulder distance apart or palms touching.  
 2.Activate your core by lifting your pelvic floor muscles and drawing in the lower belly, navel to spine.  
 3.On an exhale fold from the hips lowering your torso and arms so that they are around a 45 degree angle with the floor. Focus on a point on the floor just in front of your mat. Inhale, root down through the front foot and begin to shift your weight forwards. Starting to lift the back foot from the floor.  
 4.Begin to straighten the standing leg as you bring your body and left leg parallel with the floor. Lift the muscles of the right thigh to keep the leg engaged without locking the knee.  
 5.The toes of the back foot are pointing down to the floor and the hips are level.Keep the standing leg strong by rooting through the foot. 5.Extend out through both the raised foot and the hands.Stay for five breaths.  
 6.To come out of the pose, exhale and start to bend the standing leg as you lift the torso and lower the raised leg, with control, back into High Lunge.Inhale and step forward to Mountain Pose / Tadasana.Repeat on the other side.
